newsitem.title: USA: U.S. secondhand-smoke jury to be chosen Wednesday.
newsitem.headline: U.S. secondhand-smoke jury to be chosen Wednesday.

text.p: Final jury selection from a pool of 117 standbys will be carried out Wednesday for a $5 billion secondhand-smoke trial, the first ever in the United States, a judge said on Tuesday.
A jury of six and 10 alternates will be chosen to hear eight to 10 weeks of testimony and lawyers arguments, which were scheduled to begin on Monday in Dade County Court.

After five weeks of preliminary screening, lawyers representing nine tobacco companies and trade groups and the husband-and-wife lawyers pressing the Broin case can challenge without explanation as many as 27 potential jurors and 18 alternates.

Circuit Court Judge Robert Kaye said on Tuesday that the opposing sides would alternate juror challenges, so neither tobacco companies nor the lawyers representing an estimated 60,000 flight attendants would have an advantage.
"A lot of this is just a game of tactics," Kaye said.
The flight attendants, all non-smokers, are claiming that lung cancer and other smoking-related illnesses they suffer were caused by passengers' cigarette smoke aboard U.S. airlines before 1988.
